Smite
Azium |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 30958 | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 89295 | InChI = 1/N3.Na/c1-3-2;/q-1;+1 | InChIKey = PXIPVTKHYLBLMZ-UHFFFAOYAH | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 278547 | SMILES = [N-]=[N+]=[N-].[Na+] | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/N3.Na/c1-3-2;/q-1;+1 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = PXIPVTKHYLBLMZ-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo = 26628-22-8 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | UNNumber = [[List of UN Numbers 1601 to 1700|1687]] | EINECS = 247-852-1 | RTECS = VY8050000 | PubChem = 33557 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = NaN3 | MolarMass = 65.0099 g/mol | Appearance = colorless to white solid | Odor = odorless | Density = 1.846 g/cm3 (20 °C) | Solubility = 38.9 g/100 mL (0 °C)
40.8 g/100 mL (20 °C)
55.3 g/100 mL (100 °C) | Solvent1 = methanol | Solubility1 = 2.48 g/100 mL (25 °C) | Solvent2 = ethanol | Solubility2 = 0.22 g/100 mL (0 °C) | SolubleOther = very soluble in [[ammonia]]
slightly soluble in [[benzene]]
insoluble in [[ether]], [[acetone]], [[hexane]], [[chloroform]] | MeltingPtC = 275 | MeltingPt_notes = violent decomposition | pKa = 4.8 }} |Section3={{Chembox Structure | CrystalStruct = [[Hexagonal crystal system|Hexagonal]], [[Pearson symbol|hR12]]{{cite journal |author1=Stevens E. D. |author2=Hope H. | title = A Study of the Electron-Density Distribution in Sodium Azide, {{chem|NaN|3}} | journal = Acta Crystallographica A | year = 1977 | volume = 33 | issue = 5 | pages = 723–729 | doi = 10.1107/S0567739477001855 }} | SpaceGroup = R-3m, No. 166 }} |Section5={{Chembox Thermochemistry | DeltaHf = 21.3 kJ/mol | DeltaGf = 99.4 kJ/mol | Entropy = 70.5 J/mol K | HeatCapacity = 76.6 J/mol K }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | ExternalSDS = [http://www.inchem.org/documents/icsc/icsc/eics0950.htm ICSC 0950] | GHSPictograms = {{GHS01}} {{GHS skull and crossbones}} {{GHS health hazard}} {{GHS environment}} | GHSSignalWord = '''DANGER''' | HPhrases = {{H-phrases|300|310|400|410}} | PPhrases = {{P-phrases|260|280|301+310|501}} https://molekula.com/catalog/26628-22-8/31803515-Sodium%20azide | NFPA-H = 4 | NFPA-F = 1 | NFPA-R = 3 | NFPA-S = | FlashPtC = 300 | LD50 = 27 mg/kg (oral, rats/mice) | PEL = none{{PGCH|0560}} | IDLH = N.D. | REL = C 0.1 ppm (as HN3) [skin] C 0.3 mg/m3 (as NaN3) [skin] }} |Section8={{Chembox Related | OtherAnions = [[Sodium cyanide]] | OtherCations = [[Potassium azide]]
[[Ammonium azide]] | OtherCompounds = }}{{cite web |title=Material Safety Data Sheet |url=http://www.lamission.edu/lifesciences/MSDS/MSDS/SodiumAzide.pdf |date=November 6, 2008 |accessdate=October 2015 |publisher=Sciencelab.com}} }} '''Sodium azide''' is the [[inorganic compound]] with the [[chemical formula|formula]] NaN3. This colorless [[salt (chemistry)|salt]] is the gas-forming component in many car [[airbag]] systems. It is used for the preparation of other [[azide]] compounds. It is an [[ionic compound|ionic]] substance, is highly soluble in [[water]], and is very acutely toxic. ==Structure== Sodium azide is an ionic solid. Two [[Polymorphism (materials science)|crystalline forms]] are known, rhombohedral and hexagonal.{{Wells1984}} Both adopt layered structures. The azide anion is very similar in each form, being [[centrosymmetric]] with N–N distances of 1.18 Å. The {{chem|Na|+}} ion has [[octahedral molecular geometry|octahedral]] geometry. Each azide is linked to six Na+ centers, with three Na-N bonds to each terminal nitrogen center.{{Cite journal|title = The crystal structures of lithium, sodium and strontium azides|url = http://scripts.iucr.org/cgi-bin/paper?S0567740868002062|journal = Acta Crystallographica Section B|date = 1968-02-15|pages = 262–269|volume = 24|issue = 2|doi = 10.1107/s0567740868002062|first = G. E.|last = Pringle|first2 = D. E.|last2 = Noakes}} ==Preparation== The common synthesis method is the "[[Johannes Wislicenus|Wislicenus]] process," which proceeds in two steps from ammonia. In the first step, ammonia is converted to [[sodium amide]]: :2 Na + 2 NH3 → 2 NaNH2 + H2 The sodium amide is subsequently combined with [[nitrous oxide]]: :2 NaNH2 + N2O → NaN3 + NaOH + NH3 These reactions are the basis of the industrial route, which produced about 250 tons/y in 2004, with production increasing owing to the popularization of [[airbag]]s.{{Cite encyclopedia|title = Hydrazoic Acid and Azides|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14356007.a13_193/abstract|encyclopedia=Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry|publisher = Wiley-VCH|year = 2000|isbn = 9783527306732|doi = 10.1002/14356007.a13_193|first = Horst H.|last = Jobelius|first2 = Hans-Dieter|last2 = Scharff}} ===Laboratory methods=== Curtius and Thiele developed another production process where a nitrite ester is converted to sodium azide using hydrazine. This method is suited for laboratory preparation of sodium azide: :2 NaNO2 + 2 C2H5OH +H2SO4 → 2 C2H5ONO + Na2SO4 + 2 H2O :C2H5ONO + N2H4-H2O + NaOH → NaN3 + C2H5OH + 3 H2O Alternatively the salt can be obtained by the reaction of [[sodium nitrate]] with sodium amide.{{Holleman&Wiberg}} == Chemical reactions == Treatment of sodium azide with strong acids gives [[hydrazoic acid]], which is also extremely toxic: :{{chem|H|+}} + {{chem|N|3|-}} → {{chem|HN|3}} Aqueous solutions contain minute amounts of [[hydrogen azide]], the formation of which is described by the following equilibrium: : {{chem|N|3|-}} + {{chem|H|2|O}} {{eqm}} {{chem|HN|3}} + {{chem|OH|-}} (K = 10{{su|p=−4.6}}) Sodium azide can be destroyed by treatment with [[nitrous acid]] solution:{{ cite book | author = Committee on Prudent Practices for Handling, Storage, and Disposal of Chemicals in Laboratories, Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology, Commission on Physical Sciences, Mathematics, and Applications, National Research Council | chapter = Disposal of Waste | title = Prudent Practices in the Laboratory: Handling and Disposal of Chemicals | year = 1995 | page = 165 | publisher = National Academy Press | location = Washington, DC | isbn = 0-309-05229-7 | url = http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=4911&page=165 }} : 2 NaN3 + 2 HNO2 → 3 N2 + 2 NO + 2 NaOH ==Applications== ===Automobile airbags and airplane escape chutes === Older [[airbag]] formulations contained mixtures of oxidizers and sodium azide and other agents including ignitors and accelerants. An electronic controller detonates this mixture during an automobile crash: : 2 NaN3 → 2Na + 3 N2 The same reaction occurs upon heating the salt to approximately 300 °C. The sodium that is formed is a potential hazard alone and, in automobile airbags, it is converted by reaction with other ingredients, such as [[potassium nitrate]] and [[silica]]. In the latter case, innocuous sodium silicates are generated.{{cite journal | author = Betterton, E. A. | title = Environmental Fate of Sodium Azide Derived from Automobile Airbags | journal = Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology | year = 2003 | volume = 33 | issue = 4 | pages = 423–458 | doi = 10.1080/10643380390245002 }} Sodium azide is also used in airplane escape chutes. Newer generation air bags contain [[nitroguanidine]] or [[guanidine nitrate|similar less sensitive explosives]]. ===Organic and inorganic synthesis=== Due to its explosion hazard, sodium azide is of only limited value in industrial scale organic chemistry. In the laboratory, it is used in [[organic synthesis]] to introduce the azide functional group by displacement of [[halide]]s. The azide functional group can thereafter be converted to an [[amine]] by reduction with either [[Tin(II) chloride|SnCl2]] in ethanol or [[lithium aluminium hydride]] or a tertiary [[phosphine]], such as [[triphenylphosphine]] in the [[Staudinger reaction]], with [[Raney nickel]] or with [[hydrogen sulfide]] in pyridine. Sodium azide is a versatile precursor to other inorganic azide compounds, ''e.g.'', [[lead azide]] and [[silver azide]], which are used in explosives. ===Biochemistry and biomedical uses=== Sodium azide is a useful [[probe reagent]] and a [[preservative]]. In hospitals and laboratories, it is a [[biocide]]; it is especially important in bulk reagents and [[stock solution]]s which may otherwise support [[bacterium|bacteria]]l growth where the sodium azide acts as a [[bacteriostatic]] by inhibiting [[cytochrome oxidase]] in [[gram-negative]] bacteria; [[gram-positive]] ([[streptococci]], [[Streptococcus pneumoniae|pneumococci]], [[bacillus|lactobacilli]]) are intrinsically resistant.{{cite journal |author1=Lichstein, H. C. |author2=Soule, M. H. | title = Studies of the Effect of Sodium Azide on Microbic Growth and Respiration: I. The Action of Sodium Azide on Microbic Growth | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 47 | issue = 3 | pages = 221–230 | year = 1943 | pmid = 16560767 | pmc = 373901 }} === Agricultural uses === It is used in [[agriculture]] for pest control of soil-borne pathogens such as ''[[Meloidogyne incognita]]'' or ''[[Helicotylenchus dihystera]]''.Applications of sodium azide for control of soilborne pathogens in potatoes. Rodriguez-Kabana, R., Backman, P. A. and King, P.S., Plant Disease Reporter, 1975, Vol. 59, No. 6, pp. 528-532 ([http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/19750821668.html link]) It is also used as a [[mutagen]] for crop selection of plants such as rice,{{Cite journal|title = Mutagenic Effects of Sodium Azide in Rice1|url = https://www.crops.org/publications/cs/abstracts/20/5/CS0200050663|journal = Crop Science|date = 2000-01-01|volume = 20|issue = 5|doi = 10.2135/cropsci1980.0011183x002000050030x|first = M. Afsar|last = Awan|first2 = C. F.|last2 = Konzak|first3 = J. N.|last3 = Rutger|first4 = R. A.|last4 = Nilan|pages = 663–668}} barley{{Cite journal|title = Biological and genetic effects of combined treatments of sodium azide, gamma rays and EMS in barley|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0098847288900512|journal = Environmental and Experimental Botany|pages = 281–288|volume = 28|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/0098-8472(88)90051-2|first = Xiongying|last = Cheng|first2 = Mingwei|last2 = Gao}} or oats.{{Cite journal|title = Sodium azide mutagenesis in diploid and hexaploid oats and comparison with ethyl methanesulfonate treatments|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0098847285900437|journal = Environmental and Experimental Botany|date = 1985-02-01|pages = 7–16|volume = 25|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/0098-8472(85)90043-7|first = H. W.|last = Rines}} ==Safety considerations== Sodium azide has caused deaths for decades.{{Cite journal|title = Human Health Effects of Sodium Azide Exposure: A Literature Review and Analysis|url = http://ijt.sagepub.com/content/22/3/175|journal = International Journal of Toxicology|date = 2003-05-01|issn = 1091-5818|pmid = 12851150|pages = 175–186|volume = 22|issue = 3|doi = 10.1080/10915810305109|first = Soju|last = Chang|first2 = Steven H.|last2 = Lamm}} It is a severe poison. It possesses the NFPA 704's highest rating of 4 on the heath scale. It may be fatal in contact with skin or if swallowed.{{Cite journal|title = Two cases of sodium azide poisoning by accidental ingestion of Isoton.|url = http://jcp.bmj.com/content/28/5/350|journal = Journal of Clinical Pathology|date = 1975-05-01|issn = 1472-4146|pmid = 1150884|pages = 350–351|volume = 28|issue = 5|doi = 10.1136/jcp.28.5.350|first = S. G.|last = Richardson|first2 = C.|last2 = Giles|first3 = C. H.|last3 = Swan|pmc=475710}} Even minute amounts can cause symptoms. The toxicity of this compound is comparable to that of soluble alkali cyanides.{{cite web | url = http://hazard.com/msds/mf/baker/baker/files/s2906.htm | title = MSDS: sodium azide | id = MSDS S2906 | publisher = Mallinckrodt Baker | date = 2008-11-21 }} No toxicity has been reported from spent airbags.{{cite book|first1=Kent |last1=Olson|first2=Ilene B. |last2=Anderson|title=Poisoning & Drug Overdose, 5th Edition|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=25avFCpfQAcC|page=123}}|date=18 September 2006|publisher=McGraw-Hill Companies,Incorporated|isbn=978-0-07-144333-3|pages=123–}} It produces [[extrapyramidal symptoms]] with necrosis of the [[cerebral cortex]], [[cerebellum]], and [[basal ganglia]]. Toxicity may also include [[hypotension]],{{Cite journal|title = Kidney International - Abstract of article: Epidemic hypotension in a dialysis center caused by sodium azide|url = http://www.nature.com/ki/journal/v37/n1/abs/ki199015a.html|journal = Kidney Int|date = 1990-01-01|issn = 0085-2538|pages = 110–115|volume = 37|issue = 1|doi = 10.1038/ki.1990.15}} [[blindness]] and [[liver|hepatic]] necrosis. Sodium azide increases [[cyclic GMP]] levels in brain and liver by activation of [[guanylate cyclase]].{{Cite journal|title = Increases in cyclic GMP levels in brain and liver with sodium azide an activator of guanylate cyclase|url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v257/n5528/abs/257700a0.html|journal = Nature|date = 1975-10-23|pages = 700–702|volume = 257|issue = 5528|doi = 10.1038/257700a0|first = Hiroshi|last = Kimura|first2 = Chandra K.|last2 = Mittal|first3 = Ferid|last3 = Murad}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.inchem.org/documents/icsc/icsc/eics0950.htm International Chemical Safety Card 0950]. *[https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npg/npgd0560.html NIOSH Pocket Guide to Chemical Hazards]. *[http://www.straightdope.com/columns/061117.html ''Straight Dope'' on Sodium Azide] {{Sodium compounds}} {{Azides}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sodium Azide}} [[Category:Sodium compounds]] [[Category:Azides]] [[Category:Explosive chemicals]]

{{Infobox company |name = Talan Products |industry = [[Manufacturer]] |foundation = 1986 |type = [[Private company|Private]] |location_city = [[Cleveland]], Ohio |location_country = U.S. |locations = |area_served = Worldwide |key_people = Pete Accorti (President)
Steve Peplin (CEO) |num_employees = 100+ (2018) |products = Metal Stampings, Aluminum extrusions, assemblies, contract manufacturing |homepage = {{URL|http://www.talanproducts.com}} }} '''Talan Products''' is a [[contract manufacturing]] company specializing in progressive die [[metal stamping]] and extruded aluminum supply and fabrication, founded in 1986 and located in [[Cleveland Ohio]].{{cite web|url=http://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20130610/SUB1/306109954/0/SEARCH|title=At Talan, employees often have their say|date=6 June 2013|publisher=Crain's Cleveland Business}} Talan Products manufactures stampings and fabricated [[Extrusion|aluminum extrusions]] to the Building Products, Automotive, [[Fastener]], [[Home appliance|Appliance]], [[LED]] & [[Lighting]], Defense, and [[Solar Power]] industries.{{cite web|url=http://www.crainscleveland.com/print/article/20160814/NEWS/160819926/manufacturing-has-climbed-from-bottom|title=Manufacturing has climbed from 'bottom'|website=Crain's Cleveland Business}} Talan Products supplies component parts and assemblies to companies in North America, South America, Middle East, Australia, and Europe.{{cite web |title=Cleveland clean energy business says Trump tariffs are taking a toll |url=https://energynews.us/2018/06/08/midwest/cleveland-clean-energy-business-says-trump-tariffs-are-taking-a-toll/ |website=Energy News Network}}{{cite web |title=Talan Products supports young workers with training, mentors: Pathways to Prosperity |url=https://www.cleveland.com/expo/news/erry-2018/09/049f5ee68b5851/talan-products-supports-young.html |website=The Plain Dealer}}{{cite web |title=Talan Products has strong year outside of its comfort zone |url=https://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20111024/FREE/310249944/talan-products-has-strong-year-outside-of-its-comfort-zone |website=Crain's Cleveland Business |language=en}} ==History== Steve Peplin, John Talan and Rich Peplin collaborated together to create a manufacturing company in 1986 with a $2,100 investment. They had no manufacturing equipment but landed a customer, contracted out production, and shipped parts. Upon landing their second customer in the next year 1987, they purchased a Niagara punch press machine.{{cite web |last1=Ganzer |first1=Tony |title=Could Ohio's Renewable Energy Be A Matter Of National Security? |url=http://radio.wosu.org/post/could-ohios-renewable-energy-be-matter-national-security#stream/0 |website=WOSU-FM |language=en}} The company started out on Chatfield Ave in the neighborhood of [[West Park, Cleveland]] and moved to Cleveland's [[Detroit-Shoreway]] neighborhood in 1991 In 2006 the company moved into a building formely occupied by [[TRW Inc.]] in Cleveland's [[Collinwood]] Neighborhood. Each relocation is within the city of Cleveland's urban manufacturing areas and was facilitated by growth.{{cite web |title=Why Some See Ohio's Renewable Energy Potential As A Matter Of Economic And National Security |url=http://www.ideastream.org/news/why-some-see-ohios-renewable-energy-potential-as-a-matter-of-economic-and-national-security |website=ideastream |language=en |date=13 July 2018}} Pete Accorti joined the company as a partner in 1988. John Talan left the company in 1996. Talan Products manufactures component parts for medium and large OEM companies across many industries. In 1993 the company was first recognized for the "green initiatives" it had adopted and Pete Accorti was awarded the "Green Lantern" award by [[Crain Communications]], Crain's Cleveland Business in 2010.{{cite web |title=Waste test: a passionate manager leads Collinwood's talan products toward its goal of a sustainable stamping plant.(MANNY AWARD WINNER GREEN INITIATIVE) |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-257229023.html |publisher=Inside Business |date=1 May 2011}} ==Recognition== * 1992 #258 [[Inc. 500]] fastest growing privately held companies.{{cite web |title=Talan Products: Number 4366 on the 2009 Inc. 5000 |url=https://www.inc.com/profile/talan-products |website=Inc.com |language=en}} * 5 time winner, ICIC Inner City 100, Inducted into the Inner City 100 Hall of Fame 2017 * 4 time MANNY Award for Manufacturing Excellence 2000, 2006, 2011, 2015 {{cite web|url=http://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20150215/SUB1/302159980/talan-products-is-keeping-its-local-roots|title=Talan Products is keeping its local roots - Crain's Cleveland Business|date=12 February 2015|publisher=}} * 2007 [[Inc. 5000]] Fastest Growing Companies * 2008 Inc. Magazine, Inc 5,000 #3,441 * 2010 Green Lantern Award for sustainability{{cite web |title=Talan more frugal with energy use after rehab |url=https://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20100902/FREE/309029982/talan-more-frugal-with-energy-use-after-rehab |website=Crain's Cleveland Business |language=en}} * 2015 Crain's Fast 50 #45 {{cite web|url=http://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20141107/FAST5014/141109848|title=No. 45: Talan Products Inc.|publisher=Crain's Cleveland Business|date=4 November 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Companies based in Ohio]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Ohio]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1986]] [[Category:Manufacturing]] [[Category:Industry]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Companies based in Cleveland]]

revision.comment: Added to the description of Aluminum and titanium chair availability.
revision.text:
{{advert|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = TiLite | logo = [[File:TiLite logo.jpg|TiLite Company Logo]] | caption = The Ultimate Ride | former type = | type = | traded_as = | industry = Manufacturing | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = <!-- City, Country ({{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}}) --> | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Pasco, Washington]] | location_country = United States | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices &c. --> | area_served = Global | key_people = David Lippes (CEO) | products = [[Wheelchair]]s | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = TiSports LLC | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.tilite.com/ www.TiLite.com] | footnotes = | intl = | bodystyle = }} '''TiLite''' designs and manufactures titanium and aluminum [[wheelchairs]]. TiLite specializes in wheelchair customization (a process called TiFit) in which each wheelchair is made to users' exact specifications.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jane |last=Sander |url=http://www.kndu.com/story/20200839/pascos-tilite-company-bringing-custom-wheelchairs-to-people-around-the-world |title=Pasco's TiLite company expanding around the globe |location = Yakima, WA |publisher=Kndu.com |date=2012-11-28 |accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref>
== History ==
One of TiLite’s first models to market was called the “CrossSport”. Since then, TiLite has developed a full range of titanium and aluminum wheelchairs. TiLite wheelchairs are sold in 38 countries; TiLite is a division of TiSport, LLC, which is headquartered in Pasco, Washington.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Jason |last=Hagey |url=http://www.washingtonbusinessmag.com/home/176-the_ultimate_ride.htm |title=The Ultimate Ride - How Pasco, Wash. became home to the world’s hottest wheelchair manufacturer |publisher=Washingtonbusinessmag.com |date=Winter 2013 |accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref> In 2014, TiLite was acquired by Permobil.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.permobil.com/en/Corporate/Company/selection/Press-Releases/Permobil-acquires-TiLite|title=Permobil acquires TiLite |accessdate=2017-10-06}}</ref>
== Technology ==
TiLite uses [[titanium]] for the frames of several lines of its high-performance wheelchairs.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Boninger |first=David |url=http://pvamag.com/pn/article/3633/the_frame_game |title=The Frame Game |work=PN/Paraplegia News |publisher=Pvamag.com |issue=June 2011 |accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref> Titanium has the highest strength-to-weight ratio of any metal, it is highly durable, and it absorbs vibrations better than other common frame materials such as aluminum. These unique properties make it desirable, but because titanium is difficult to refine and requires expertise and precision in welding and bending, it is a more costly material. TiLite makes wheelchairs in both titanium and aluminum. While the company's titanium chairs are slightly lighter in weight and more durable, their aluminum wheelchairs are more economical and sufficient for most users. <ref>{{cite magazine|first=Bob |last=Vogel |url=http://newmobility.com/articleView.cfm?id=11711 |title=The Titanium Revolution Revisited |publisher=New Mobility |date=September 2010 |accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref> The design and manufacturing process uses [[parametric model]]ling,<ref>{{cite book|last=Sorby|first=Dennis K. Lieu, Sheryl|title=Visualization, modeling, and graphics for engineering design|year=2009|publisher=Delmar Cengage Learning|location=Clifton Park, NY|isbn=978-1401842499|pages=A2–A4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lHO79rg6VT8C&q=TiLite#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=1st}}</ref> [[computer aided design]] and [[finite element analysis]] technologies to optimize design and material choices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.designnews.com/document.asp?doc_id=230479&dfpPParams=ind_182,aid_230479&dfpLayout=article |title=Features – TiLite Races Ahead with Custom Wheelchair Design |first=Beth |last=Stackpole |publisher=Design News |date=2011-05-04 |accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref>
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
== Additional sources ==
*“TiLite Makes Marketing, Product & Brand Management Moves” ''Mobility Management'', 8 March 2013. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NPg0e-JGz-A TiLite Wheelchairs on ''[[Made in America (TV program)|Made in America]]'' – Full Episode] (TiLite official [[YouTube]] channel)
== External links == {{Portal|Disability|Engineering|Companies}} *{{Official website|http://www.tilite.com/|TiLite.com}}

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=April 2014}} {{refimprove|date=April 2011}} }}
[[File:BNSF 5350 20040808 Prairie du Chien WI.jpg|right|300px|thumb|American freight service]] A '''train inspection system''' is one of various systems of inspection which are essential to maintain the safe running of [[rail transport]].
Because [[safety]] is of high importance when [[railroad car|train cars]] move across the rails, there must be [[inspection]]s. The cars are heavy and have moving parts that can break or become defective. Worn or broken parts can drag, pound, and generally destroy the cars and the [[Track (rail transport)|track]] structure they run on. Parts and [[cargo|loads]] must not extend outside the limits of the car, and there should be no leaking of the cars' contents.
Quality inspections are needed not just before a [[train]] is moved, but also as it travels to its destination.
==Overview== [[File:HBD DD1.jpg|right|200px|thumb|A hot bearing detector w/ dragging equipment unit]] There are several levels of inspection on railroad equipment. Inspections are continuous, starting when the car is being built and repeated at regular intervals.
Before the train begins its journey, the [[locomotive]]s and the [[railroad car|cars]] are checked. This is done by mechanical department workers, sometimes [[camera]]s and [[3D scanner|scanners]] are also used. Some of the items certified ''good to go'' are things like the [[braking system]] including hand-brake release, brake application, condition of the air valves, piping and hoses, communication equipment, and many more. Very much like the [[checklist]] an airline might use. When the pretrip work is done, the train is considered safe to move.
Once the movement begins, the train is continuously watched by employees, scanners and monitors. These are sometimes called "in motion defect detectors" or [[defect detector]]s (DD). <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:WISE with Bungalow JPG.jpg|right|200px|thumb|WISE Scanner Location]] -->
==Technologies== As the railroad has evolved from block stations and control towers to a centralized dispatching system, they have also moved to more advanced inspection tools. The technologies in use today vary from a simplistic paddle and switch to infrared [[thermography]], [[3D scanner|laser scanning]], and even [[Ultrasonic testing|ultrasonic audio analysis]]. These devices are used to inspect engines, cars and the loads on them.<ref name="aar-hightech">{{cite web|url=http://www.aar.org/~/media/aar/Background-Papers/High-Tech-Advances.ashx|title=Error|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref>
The systems used on [[North America]]n and other railways fall into a dozen or so major groups, some are listed below.
;Wheel impact load detector (WILD)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aar.org/~/media/aar/past-events/2011-03-15-NARMO/CN-Wild-History.ashx|title=Error|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="lechowicz-hunt">{{cite web| url=http://www.ntsb.gov/events/symp_rec/proceedings/authors/lechowicz.htm| title=Monitoring and Managing Wheel Condition and Loading| date=May 3–5, 1999| last=Lechowicz| first=Stephen| last2=Hunt| first2=Chris| location=Arlington, Virginia}}</ref> [[File:Railway-defect-detectors-sensors.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Sensors for a railway wheel impact load monitor, Lara, Victoria, Australia]] High impact wheels have some defect where it does not roll smoothly along the track, A flaw in a wheel causes vibrations or banging. This is very destructive to the track structure and the [[rolling stock]].
;Weigh in motion (WIM) {{main|Weigh in motion}} Checks for overloads or shifted loads that can be dangerous.<ref name="lechowicz-hunt" />
;Truck hunting [[File:Hunting oscillation section ja 150px.gif|right|200px|thumb|Truck hunting]] Looks for ''[[hunting oscillation]]'' of the [[bogie|trucks]] or [[Wheelset (rail transport)|wheelset]]; a lateral movement in the [[track gauge|gauge]] of the track, like drifting back and forth in a lane of traffic. This action can increase above a certain speed to the point the wheel flanges impact the rails, potentially causing damage to both. There is also force absorbed by this action that will affect the energy consumption of train operations.
;Truck performance [[File:Bogie Tracking Behaviour Monitor - TBOGI system.jpg|thumb|Truck hunting and performance detector—TBOGI system]] Is stiff or poorly steering or axle sets that don't follow the path of the track correctly. Presents itself like 'dog tracking" where the [[Wheelset (rail transport)|trucks]] are biased to run against the flange on one side or the other. Truck performance defects include tracking position and angle of attack on a per-axle basis, as well as rotation, shift, inter-axle misalignment, and tracking error on a per-bogie basis. Truck performance detectors can provide early detection of bogie defects, and early warning of derailment risks through flange climb or rail break.<ref name="The Challenges of Integrating Novel Wayside Rolling Stock Monitoring Technologies: A Case Study">{{cite paper|last=Bladon|first=Paul|title=The Challenges of Integrating Novel Wayside Rolling Stock Monitoring Technologies: A Case Study|date=2015|publisher=[[International Heavy Haul Association]]|location=Perth, Australia|url=http://www.railway-technology.com/downloads/whitepapers/track/tbogi-bogie/|accessdate=June 21, 2015}}</ref>
;Acoustic bearing detectors Listens with special [[microphone]]s for internal [[Bearing (mechanical)|bearing]] defects as the equipment moves across the detector.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fra.dot.gov/downloads/Research/ord0006ii.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527152928/http://www.fra.dot.gov/downloads/Research/ord0006ii.pdf |archivedate=2010-05-27 |df= }}</ref><ref name="atsi">{{cite web|url=http://www.aar.org/~/media/aar/past-events/2011-03-15-NARMO/From-ATSI-to-TDTI.ashx|title=Error|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref> These are very sensitive and can detect problems before the bearing fails.
;High wheel temperature detectors [[File:Phoenix 2FBOA Kopie.png|right|200px|thumb|Hot box and hot wheel detection system, PHOENIX MB (SST Signal & System Technik GmbH)]] Look for hot and cold wheels which are generally caused by braking equipment failures.
;Bearing temperature scanners This type of defect detector uses ultra sensitive [[infrared]] cameras called [[pyrometer]]s. These devices take the [[temperature]] of each bearing as it passes by the scanner. This data is then compared to preset "Alarm limits". If the whole [[consist]] is without problems, the train is passed. If however there is overheating in one or more of the bearings (a [[hot box]]), an alarm is given.
These messages can be by radio to the train crew or might be sent to the [[dispatch center]] for handling. The data is also used to detect a trend over several locations that might predict a future failure. If an alarm is sent, the train is stopped, and either the defect is corrected or the offending car is removed for repair. Many [[derailment]]s are avoided by these devices which is why thousands of them are in use on rail systems across the world.
;Dragging equipment detectors As the name suggests, they are able to detect things hanging or dragging under the cars. These consist of a series of plates mounted on a pivot shaft. An object hanging or dragging will contact the plates, moving them and breaking a circuit. This will trigger an alarm and alert the crew. Many are stand-alone detectors, but most often are integrated into bearing temperature scanning locations.
;High/wide sensors [[Image:Lademass EBO.png|thumb| Railway clearance G1 and G2 (Germany)]] {{see also|structure gauge||loading gauge}} These are able to measure the height and width of rolling stock, so that cars and loads which won't fit under bridges or through tunnels are stopped. Most often they are optical line of sight devices that trigger an alarm when the beam is broken. They are often seen at a bearing temperature scanning locations, they then report out as part of the detectors regular train inspection report. Mounted on poles or a bridge structure, the optical line is adjusted for a set height and width, it can then send an alarm when something too big to fit the clearance limits ahead passes its view.
;Derailment detector Is a simple "broken wire" type device that notifies the train crew they are off the track somewhere in their train.
;Pantograph inspection<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pantoinspect.com|title=Pantoinspect - Image House|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref> [[File:Pantograph inspection scanner.JPG|thumb|An automated scanner inspects the pantograph of a passing train.]] {{anchor|Pantograph inspection}}A system which monitors the integrity of the [[Pantograph_(rail)|pantograph]]. These are normally based on a [[machine_vision|vision system]] which takes pictures of the pantographs and performs an analysis based on computer vision algorithms. A pantograph uses a [[graphite|carbon]] strip to conduct electricity between the [[Overhead_line|catenary]] and the [[Pantograph_(rail)|pantograph]]. When these are damaged or worn out, the [[Pantograph_(rail)|pantograph]] can tear down the [[Overhead_line|catenary]] causing [[train]] delays.
;Wheel Profile monitors<ref name="aar-hightech"/> [[File:WPD Prototype.jpg|right|200px|thumb|A laser wheel profile detector]] These laser and optical scanning devices make images of the [[flange]] and [[tread]]. These measurements are compared with acceptable dimensions. When worn beyond limits, the wheels are scheduled for replacement. If beyond a safe level the axle set is removed from service.
;Trend monitoring systems These [[back office]] systems are predictive, finding equipment problems as they start to develop.<ref name="atsi" />
== See also == * [[Defect detector]]
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.southern-tech.com/products/dds.aspx/ Southern Tech] * [http://www.progressiverailroading.com/news/article.asp?id=2696 Progressive Railroading] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081123012420/http://www.ntsb.gov/events/symp_rec/proceedings/authors/lechowicz.htm International Symposium on Transportation Recorders] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110228143928/http://www.aar.com/wdprc/ Association of American Railroads]

page.title: United States President's Commission on CIA Activities within the United States

revision.text:
{{Infobox U.S. Presidential Commission | name = Rockefeller Commission | longtitle = United States President's Commission on CIA Activities within the United States | shorttitle = | othershorttitles = | depiction = RockefellerCommissionSwearingIn1975.png | depictioncaption = Swearing-in of the Rockefeller Commission in 1975: Nelson A. Rockefeller, [[Lyman L. Lemnitzer]], [[Ronald Reagan]], [[Edgar F. Shannon, Jr.]], [[David W. Belin]], [[John T. Connor]], [[C. Douglas Dillon]], [[Erwin N. Griswold]], and [[Lane Kirkland]] | depictionalt = | status = | establishedpresident = | establisheddate = | executiveorder = | disbandeddate = | chairperson = [[Nelson Rockefeller]] | othermembers = [[Lyman L. Lemnitzer]]
[[Ronald Reagan]]
[[Edgar F. Shannon, Jr.]]
[[David W. Belin]]
[[John T. Connor]]
[[C. Douglas Dillon]]
[[Erwin N. Griswold]]
[[Lane Kirkland]] | purpose = | policy_areas = | summary = }} __NOTOC__ The '''United States President's Commission on CIA Activities within the United States''' was set up under President [[Gerald Ford]] in 1975 to investigate the activities of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] and other intelligence agencies within the [[United States of America|United States]]. The commission was led by the Vice President, [[Nelson Rockefeller]], and is sometimes referred to as the '''Rockefeller Commission'''. The commission was created in response to a December 1974 report in ''[[The New York Times]]'' that the CIA had conducted illegal domestic activities, including experiments on U.S. citizens, during the 1960s. The commission issued a single report in 1975, touching upon certain [[CIA]] abuses including mail opening and surveillance of domestic dissident groups. It publicized [[Project MKUltra]], a CIA [[mind control]] study. It also studied issues relating to the [[John F. Kennedy assassination]], specifically the head snap as seen in the [[Zapruder film]] (first shown on television in 1975), and the possible presence of [[E. Howard Hunt]] and [[Frank Sturgis]] in [[Dallas, Texas]].[http://www.aarclibrary.org/publib/contents/church/contents_church_reports_rockcomm.htm Michigan State University Libraries - Electronic Resources] A larger investigation, the [[Church Committee]], was set up on 27 January 1975 by the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]]. The [[Nedzi Committee]] was created in the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] on 19 February 1975. It was replaced by the [[Pike Committee]] five months later. In July 1975, ''The New York Times'' reported that unnamed staff sources within the Rockefeller Commission said that [[Sidney Gottlieb]] commanded the [[Project MKUltra|CIA's LSD experimentation program]], was personally involved in the experiment that killed researcher [[Frank Olson]], then destroyed the program's records in 1973.{{cite news |last=M. Horrock |first=Nicholas |date=July 18, 1975 |title=Destruction of LSD Data Laid to C.I.A. Aide in '73 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/07/18/archives/destruction-of-lsd-data-laid-to-cia-aide-in-73-destruction-of-lsd.html?mcubz=1 |work=The New York Times |page=1 |access-date=September 13, 2017}} ==See also== * [[Church Committee]] * [[COINTELPRO]] * [[Family Jewels (Central Intelligence Agency)]] * [[Human experimentation in the United States]] * [[Human rights violations by the CIA]] * [[Nedzi Committee]] * [[Pike Committee]] * [[Plausible denial]] * [[Project MKUltra]] * [[Hughes–Ryan Act]] * [[Werner Spitz]] == References == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Lee, Martin A. Shlain, Bruce. 1992. ''[[Acid Dreams (book)|Acid Dreams: The Complete Social History of LSD: The CIA, the Sixties, and Beyond]]''. Grove Press. {{ISBN|0-8021-3062-3}}. * {{cite book|last=Kitts|first=Kenneth|title=Presidential Commissions & National Security: The Politics of Damage Control|year=2006|publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers |location=Boulder, Colo|isbn=978-1-58826-404-6|chapter=Chapter 3, The Politics of Spying: The Rockefeller Commission and the CIA}} ==External links== * [http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/NSAEBB/NSAEBB543-Ford-White-House-Altered-Rockefeller-Commission-Report/ Gerald Ford White House Altered Rockefeller Commission Report in 1975; Removed Section on CIA Assassination Plots] * [http://history-matters.com/archive/church/rockcomm/contents.htm Rockefeller Commission Report] – the full text of the report, as scans * Another version of the [http://www.maryferrell.org/wiki/index.php/Rockefeller_Commission Rockefeller Commission Report] including interview transcripts, memos, correspondence and other Commission files released under the JFK Records Act. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070312095833/http://bss.sfsu.edu/fischer/IR%20360/Readings/pike.htm The Pike Committee Investigations and the CIA] {{US Intelligence Reform Attempts 1947-2005}} {{authority control}} [[Category:Central Intelligence Agency]] [[Category:Mind control]] [[Category:Nelson A. Rockefeller]] [[Category:Official enquiries concerning the assassination of John F. Kennedy]] [[Category:Presidency of Gerald Ford]] [[Category:Surveillance scandals]] [[Category:United States Presidential Commissions|CIA Activities within the United States, United States President's Commission on]] {{US-gov-stub}}

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2001:8004:1480:1207:5528:AD5C:76F8:7C69|2001:8004:1480:1207:5528:AD5C:76F8:7C69]] ([[User talk:2001:8004:1480:1207:5528:AD5C:76F8:7C69|talk]]) to last version by PlyrStar93
revision.text:
'''Uranium in the environment''' refers to the science of the sources, environmental behaviour, and effects of [[uranium]] on humans and other animals. Uranium is weakly [[radioactive]] and remains so because of its long [[half-life|physical half-life]] (4.468 billion years for [[uranium-238]]). The [[biological half-life]] (the average time it takes for the human body to eliminate half the amount in the body) for uranium is about 15 days.<ref name="hyperphysics">{{cite web |url= http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/nuclear/biohalf.html#c2 |title= Biological Half Lives |author= Georgia State University }}</ref> Normal functioning of the [[kidney]], [[brain]], [[liver]], [[heart]], and numerous other systems can be affected by uranium exposure, because uranium is a [[toxic metal]].<ref name=Craft04>{{cite journal | title = Depleted and natural uranium: chemistry and toxicological effects |author1=E. S. Craft |author2=A. W. Abu-Qare |author3=M. M. Flaherty |author4=M. C. Garofolo |author5=H. L. Rincavage |author6=M. B. Abou-Donia | journal = Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health Part B: Critical Reviews | year = 2004 | volume = 7 | issue = 4 | pmid = 15205046 |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/section?content=a714111273&fulltext=713240929#uteb_12817_tab07 | pages = 297–317 | doi = 10.1080/10937400490452714}}</ref> The use of depleted uranium (DU) in [[munitions]] is controversial because of questions about potential long-term health effects.<ref name=MillerMcClain /><ref name="John E 2009">{{cite journal | last1 = Pattison | first1 = John E. | last2 = Hugtenburg | first2 = Richard P. | last3 = Green | first3 = Stuart | year = 2010 | title = Enhancement of Natural Background Gamma-radiation Dose around Uranium Micro-particles in the Human Body | url = | journal = Journal of the Royal Society Interface | volume = 7 | issue = 45| pages = 603–611 | doi = 10.1098/rsif.2009.0300 | pmc = 2842777 }}</ref>
==Natural occurrence== [[File:UraniumUSGOV.jpg|thumb|Uranium ore]] [[Uranium]] is a naturally occurring element found in low levels within all rock, soil, and water. This is the highest-numbered element to be found naturally in significant quantities on earth. According to the [[United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation]] the normal concentration of uranium in soil is 300 μg/kg to 11.7 mg/kg.<ref>{{Cite book| url = http://www.unscear.org/unscear/en/publications/1993.html |author=United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation |title=Sources and effects of ionizing radiation : UNSCEAR 1993 Report to the General Assembly, with Scientific Annexes | publisher = [[United Nations]] | isbn = 92-1-142200-0 | year = 1993}}</ref>
It is considered to be more plentiful than [[antimony]], [[beryllium]], [[cadmium]], [[gold]], [[mercury (element)|mercury]], [[silver]], or [[tungsten]] and is about as abundant as [[tin]], [[arsenic]] or [[molybdenum]]. It is found in many minerals including [[uraninite]] (most common uranium ore), [[autunite]], [[uranophane]], [[torbernite]], and [[coffinite]]. Significant concentrations of uranium occur in some substances such as [[phosphate]] rock deposits, and minerals such as [[lignite]], and [[monazite]] sands in uranium-rich [[ore]]s (it is recovered commercially from these sources).
[[Seawater]] contains about 3.3 [[parts per billion]] of uranium by weight, approximately (3.3 µg/kg) or, 3.3 micrograms per [[liter]] of seawater.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OeEUcIRsIwAC&pg=PA598&lpg=PA598&dq=Radium+and+thorium+isotopes+in+the+surface+waters+of+the+East+Pacific+and+coastal+southern+California.+Earth+Planet.+Sci.+Lett.,+39:+235249.&source=bl&ots=0aDXxdrln8&sig=T7Ne1hE0kHZ44OiV-8tr229yQQw&hl=ga&sa=X&ei=6KQGVOaqB4ue7Aby8IDACQ&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%20thorium&f=false |title=Isotopes of the Earth's Hydrosphere By V.I. Ferronsky, V.A. Polyakov, pg 399}}</ref> as uranium(VI) forms soluble [[carbonate]] complexes. The extraction of uranium from seawater has been considered as a means of obtaining the element.
==Sources of uranium==
===Mining and milling=== The radiation hazards of uranium mining and milling were not appreciated in the early years, resulting in workers exposed to high levels of radiation. Conventional uranium ore treatment mills create radioactive waste in the form of [[tailings]], which contain uranium, radium, and polonium. Consequently, uranium mining results in "the unavoidable radioactive contamination of the environment by solid, liquid and gaseous wastes".<ref>[[Benjamin K. Sovacool]] (2011). ''[[Contesting the Future of Nuclear Power]]: A Critical Global Assessment of Atomic Energy'', [[World Scientific]], p. 137.</ref> Inhalation of [[radon]] gas caused sharp increases in lung cancers among underground uranium miners employed in the 1940s and 1950s.<ref name="ama-assn629">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1001/jama.1989.03430050045024 | volume = 262 | issue = 5 | pages = 629–633 | last = Roscoe | first = R. J. |author2=K. Steenland |author3=W. E. Halperin |author4=J. J. Beaumont |author5=R. J. Waxweiler | title = Lung cancer mortality among nonsmoking uranium miners exposed to radon daughters | journal = JAMA | accessdate = 2007-08-09 | date = 1989-08-04 | url = http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/262/5/629 | pmid = 2746814 }}</ref>
In the 1940s and 1950s, uranium mill tailings were released with impunity into water sources, and the radium leached from these tailings contaminated thousands of miles of the Colorado River system. Between 1966 and 1971, thousands of homes and commercial buildings in the Colorado Plateau region were "found to contain anomalously high concentrations of radon, after being built on uranium tailings taken from piles under the authority of the Atomic Energy Commission".<ref>Benjamin K. Sovacool (2011). ''Contesting the Future of Nuclear Power: A Critical Global Assessment of Atomic Energy'', World Scientific, p. 138.</ref>
===Metal=== {{See also|Depleted uranium}} [[File:30mm DU slug.jpg|thumb|right|DU penetrator from the PGU-14/B incendiary 30 mm round]]
Depleted uranium (DU) is useful because of its very high [[density]] of 19.1 [[Gram|g]]/cm<sup>3</sup> (68.4% denser than lead). Civilian uses include counterweights in aircraft, radiation shielding in medical [[radiation therapy]] and industrial [[radiography]] equipment, and containers used to transport radioactive materials. Military uses include defensive armor plating and [[Armor-piercing shot and shell|armor-piercing]] [[projectiles]].
Uranium metal can disperse into the air and water, [[United Nations Environment Programme|United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)]] study says in part: : "The most important concern is the potential for future [[radioactive contamination|groundwater contamination]] by corroding penetrators (ammunition tips made out of DU). The munition tips recovered by the UNEP team had already decreased in mass by 10-15% in this way. This [[Corrosion|rapid corrosion]] speed underlines the importance of monitoring the water quality at the DU sites on an annual basis."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.unep.org/Documents.multilingual/Default.asp?DocumentID=241&ArticleID=3036 |title=UNEP confirms low-level DU contamination |date=March 22, 2002 |publisher=[[United Nations Environment Programme]]}}</ref>
===Combustion=== Studies of depleted uranium aerosol exposure suggest that uranium combustion product particles would quickly settle out of the air,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deploymentlink.osd.mil/du_library/du_ii/du_ii_tabl1.htm |title=Depleted uranium |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614010814/http://www.deploymentlink.osd.mil/du_library/du_ii/du_ii_tabl1.htm |archivedate=June 14, 2006 }}</ref> and thus could not affect populations more than a few kilometres from target areas.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/00004032-200304000-00014 |author=C. Mitsakou, K. Eleftheriadis, C. Housiadas & M. Lazaridis |title=Modeling of the dispersion of depleted uranium aerosol |journal=[[Health Physics (journal)|Health Physics]] |volume=84 |issue=4 |pages=538–544 |date=April 2003 |url=http://journals.lww.com/health-physics/Abstract/2003/04000/Modeling_of_the_Dispersion_of_Depleted_Uranium.14.aspx |pmid=12705453}}</ref>
The U.S. has admitted that there have been over 100 "friendly fire" incidents in which members of the U.S. military have been struck by DU munitions, and that an unknown number have been exposed to DU via inhalation of combustion products from burning DU munitions.
===Corrosion=== It has been reported that the corrosion of uranium in a silica rich aqueous solution forms both [[uranium dioxide]] and [[uranium trioxide]].<ref>{{cite conference |conference=Goldschmidt Conference |date=7–12 September 2003 |location=[[Kurashiki]], [[Japan]] |url=http://goldschmidt.info/2003/Abstracts.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] abstract |author=E. R. Trueman, S. Black, D. Read & M. E. Hodson |title=Alteration of depleted uranium metal}}</ref>
In pure water, [[schoepite]] {(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>8</sub>O<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>12</sub>.12(H<sub>2</sub>O)} is formed <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://webmineral.com/data/Schoepite.shtml |title=Schoepite Mineral Data |publisher= |accessdate=August 28, 2010}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2010}} in the first week and then after four months [[studtite]] {(UO<sub>2</sub>)O<sub>2</sub>·4(H<sub>2</sub>O)} was formed.
Uranium [[metal]] reacts with [[water]] to form [[hydrogen]] gas, this reaction forms [[uranium dioxide]] and 2% to 9% [[uranium hydride]]. It is important to note that the rate of corrosion due to water is far greater than that caused by oxygen at temperatures around {{convert|100|C|F}}. At pH values below 2 the corrosion rate at 100 °C goes down greatly, while as pH values go from 7 upwards the corrosion rate declines. Gamma irradiation has little effect on the corrosion rate.<ref>{{cite journal |author=M. McD Baker, L. N. Less & S. Orman |title=Uranium + water reaction. Part 1.—Kinetics, products and mechanism |journal=Transactions of the Faraday Society |volume=62 |pages=2513–2524 |year=1966 |doi=10.1039/TF9666202513}}</ref>
Oxygen gas inhibits the corrosion of uranium by water. .<ref>{{cite journal |author=M. McD Baker, L. N. Less & S. Orman |title=Uranium + water reaction. Part 2.—Effect of oxygen and other gases |journal=Transactions of the Faraday Society |volume=62 |pages=2525–2530 |year=1966 |doi=10.1039/TF9666202525}}</ref>
===Nuclear waste=== Spent [[uranium dioxide]] fuel is very insoluble in water, it is likely to release uranium (and [[fission products]]) even more slowly than borosilicate glass when in contact with water.<ref>B.E. Burakov, M.I Ojovan, W.E. Lee. Crystalline Materials for Actinide Immobilisation, Imperial College Press, London, 198 pp. (2010). {{cite web |url=http://www.icpress.co.uk/engineering/p652.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309093650/http://www.icpress.co.uk/engineering/p652.html |archivedate=2012-03-09 |df= }}</ref>
Note that while the vast majority of the uranium is removed by [[PUREX]] [[nuclear reprocessing]], a small amount of uranium is left in the [[raffinate]] from the first cycle of the PUREX process. In addition because of the decay of the transplutonium [[minor actinides]] and the residual [[plutonium]] in the waste the concentration of uranium will increase on the waste. This will occur on a time scale of hundreds and thousands of years.
==Health effects== [[File:Trionuraniumanti.png|thumb|right|Tiron is a [[phenol]]oic [[aromatic]] [[sulfonic acid|disulfonic acid]]. It is an alternative to bicarbonate which has already been tested in animals.]]
Soluble uranium salts are [[toxic]], though less so than those of other heavy metals such as [[lead]] or [[mercury (element)|mercury]]. The organ which is most affected is the [[kidney]]. Soluble uranium salts are readily excreted in the [[urine]], although some accumulation in the kidneys does occur in the case of chronic exposure. The [[World Health Organization]] has established a daily "tolerated intake" of soluble uranium salts for the general public of 0.5 μg/kg body weight (or 35 μg for a 70 kg adult): exposure at this level is not thought to lead to any significant kidney damage.<ref name="IAEA">{{Cite web |url=http://www.iaea.org/NewsCenter/Features/DU/faq_depleted_uranium.shtml |publisher=[[International Atomic Energy Agency]] |title=Focus: Depleted Uranium |accessdate=August 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100318003818/http://www.iaea.org/NewsCenter/Features/DU/faq_depleted_uranium.shtml |archivedate=March 18, 2010 |df= }}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2010}}
The [[antidote]] for uranium in humans is [[bicarbonate]], which is used because uranium (VI) forms complexes with [[carbonate]]. An alternative is to use tiron (sodium 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonate).<ref>{{cite journal |author=O. Braun, C. Contino, M.-H. Hengé-Napoli, E. Ansoborlo and B. Pucci |year=1999 |title=Development of an in vitro test for screening of chelators of uranium |journal=[[Analusis]] |volume=27 |pages=65–68 |doi=10.1051/analusis:1999108}}</ref>
===Humans=== {{Further|Uranium#Human exposure}}
====Cancer==== In 1950, the US Public Health service began a comprehensive study of uranium miners, leading to the first publication of a statistical correlation between cancer and uranium mining, released in 1962.<ref name=Dawson>Dawson, Susan E, and Gary E Madsen. "Uranium Mine Workers, Atomic Downwinders, and the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act." In Half Lives & Half-Truths: Confronting the Radioactive Legacies of the Cold War, 117-143. Santa Fe: School For Advanced Research, 2007)</ref> The federal government eventually regulated the standard amount of [[radon]] in mines, setting the level at 0.3 [[Health effects of radon#Concentration units|WL]] on January 1, 1969.<ref name=Brugge>Brugge, Doug, Timothy Benally, and Esther Yazzie-Lewis. The Navajo People and Uranium Mining. Albuquerque : University of New Mexico Press, 2006.</ref>
Out of 69 69 present and former uranium milling sites in 12 states, 24 have been abandoned, and are the responsibility of the [[US Department of Energy]].<ref>[http://www.atomictraveler.com/MillDecommissioningData.pdf Decommissioning of U.S. Uranium Production Facilities]</ref> Accidental releases from uranium mills include the 1979 [[Church Rock uranium mill spill]] in New Mexico, called the largest accident of nuclear-related waste in US history, and the 1986 [[Sequoyah Corporation Fuels Release]] in Oklahoma.<ref name=Brugge2>Doug Brugge, et al, "The Sequoyah Corporation Fuels Release and the Church Rock Spill", ''American Journal of Public Health'', September 2007, Vol., 97, No. 9, pp. 1595-1600.</ref>
In 1990, [[United States Congress|Congress]] passed the [[Radiation Exposure Compensation Act]] (RECA), granting [[reparation (legal)|reparations]] for those affected by mining, with [[amendments]] passed in 2000 to address criticisms with the original act.<ref name = Dawson/>
====Depleted uranium exposure==== {{See also|Depleted uranium}} [[File:Kosovo uranium NATO bombing1999.png|thumb|Sites in Kosovo and southern Central Serbia where NATO aviation used depleted uranium munitions during 1999 bombing]] The use of depleted uranium (DU) in [[munitions]] is controversial because of questions about potential long-term health effects.<ref name=MillerMcClain /><ref name="John E 2009"/> Normal functioning of the [[kidney]], [[brain]], [[liver]], [[heart]], and numerous other systems can be affected by uranium exposure, because uranium is a [[toxic metal]].<ref name=Craft04 /> The aerosol produced during impact and combustion of depleted uranium munitions can potentially contaminate wide areas around the impact sites leading to possible inhalation by human beings.<ref name="ncbi.nlm.nih.gov">Mitsakou C, Eleftheriadis K, Housiadas C, Lazaridis M [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12705453 Modeling of the dispersion of depleted uranium aerosol.] 2003 Apr, Retrieved January 15, 2009</ref> During a three-week period of conflict in 2003 in [[Iraq]], 1,000 to 2,000 tonnes of DU munitions were used.<ref name="gaurdian2003">Paul Brown, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/apr/25/internationaleducationnews.armstrade Gulf troops face tests for cancer] ''guardian.co.uk'' 25 April 2003, Retrieved February 3, 2009</ref>
The actual acute and chronic toxicity of DU is also a point of medical controversy. Multiple studies using cultured cells and laboratory rodents suggest the possibility of [[leukemia|leukemogenic]], [[gene]]tic, [[reproduction|reproductive]], and [[neurological]] effects from chronic exposure.<ref name=MillerMcClain>{{cite journal | author = Miller AC, McClain D. | title = A review of depleted uranium biological effects: in vitro and in vivo studies | journal = Rev Environ Health | date = Jan–Mar 2007 | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 75–89 | pmid = 17508699 | doi=10.1515/REVEH.2007.22.1.75 | last2 = McClain}}</ref> A 2005 [[epidemiology]] review concluded: "In aggregate the human epidemiological evidence is consistent with increased risk of birth defects in offspring of persons exposed to DU."<ref name="pmid16124873">{{cite journal |author1=Rita Hindin, Doug Brugge |author2=Bindu Panikkar |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Teratogenicity of depleted uranium aerosols: A review from an epidemiological perspective |journal=[[Environmental Health (journal)|Environmental Health]] |volume=4 |issue=1 |page=17 |year=2005 |pmid=16124873 |pmc=1242351 |doi=10.1186/1476-069X-4-17 |url=http://www.ehjournal.net/content/4/1/17}}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]], the directing and coordinating authority for health within the United Nations which is responsible for setting health research norms and standards, providing technical support to countries and monitoring and assessing health trends,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.who.int/about/en/ |title= World Health Organization |author= World Health Organization }}</ref> states that no risk of reproductive, developmental, or carcinogenic effects have been reported in humans due to DU exposure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs257/en/ |title=Depleted uranium |author=World Health Organization |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815092349/http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs257/en/ |archivedate=August 15, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.who.int/ionizing_radiation/env/du/en/index.html |title = Depleted uranium |author = World Health Organization |access-date = 2011-01-26 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110126230758/http://www.who.int/ionizing_radiation/env/du/en/index.html |archive-date = 2011-01-26 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> This report has been criticized by Dr. Keith Baverstock for not including possible long-term effects of DU on human body.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.kbaverstock.org/EVIDENCDETOBELGIANCOMM.pdf |title= Depleted Uranium Weapons |author= Keith Baverstock }}</ref>
====Birth defects==== Most scientific studies have found no link between uranium and birth defects, but some claim statistical correlations between soldiers exposed to DU, and those who were not, concerning reproductive abnormalities.
One study concluded that epidemiological evidence is consistent with an increased risk of birth defects in the offspring of persons exposed to DU.<ref name="pmid16124873" /> Environmental groups and others have expressed concern about the health effects of depleted uranium,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/jul/10/iraq.armstrade |title=Our gift to Iraq |author=A. L. Kennedy |date=July 10, 2003 |publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> and there is some debate over the matter. Some people have raised concerns about the use of this material, particularly in munitions, because of its mutagenicity,<ref name=Monleau06>{{cite journal |author=Marjorie Monleau, Michel De Méo, François Paquet, Valérie Chazel, Gérard Duménil & Marie Donnadieu-Claraz |title=Genotoxic and inflammatory effects of depleted uranium particles inhaled by rats |journal=[[Toxicological Sciences]] |volume=89 |issue=1 |pages=287–295 |date=January 2006 |pmid=16221956 |doi=10.1093/toxsci/kfj010 |url=http://toxsci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/89/1/287}}</ref> teratogenicity in mice,<ref name=Arfsten01>{{cite journal |author=Darryl P. Arfsten, Kenneth R. Still & Glenn D. Ritchie |title=A review of the effects of uranium and depleted uranium exposure on reproduction and fetal development |journal=[[Toxicology and Industrial Health]] |volume=17 |issue=5–10 |pages=180–191 |date=June 2001 |pmid=12539863 |url=http://tih.sagepub.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12539863 |doi=10.1191/0748233701th111oa}}</ref><ref name=Domingo01>{{cite journal |author=J. L. Domingo |title=Reproductive and developmental toxicity of natural and depleted uranium: a review |journal=Reprod. Toxicol. |volume=15 |issue=6 |pages=603–9 |year=2001 |pmid=11738513 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0890623801001812 |doi=10.1016/S0890-6238(01)00181-2}}</ref> and neurotoxicity,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=W. Briner |author2=J. Murray |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Effects of short-term and long-term depleted uranium exposure on open-field behavior and brain lipid oxidation in rats |journal=[[Neurotoxicology and Teratology]] |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=135–44 |year=2005 |pmid=15681127 |doi=10.1016/j.ntt.2004.09.001 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0892-0362(04)00132-1}}</ref> and its suspected carcinogenic potential. Additional concerns address unexploded DU munitions leeching into groundwater over time.<ref>{{cite journal |author=S. C. Sheppard, M. I. Sheppard, M. O. Gallerand & B. Sanipelli |title=Derivation of ecotoxicity thresholds for uranium |journal=[[Journal of Environmental Radioactivity]] |volume=79 |issue=1 |pages=55–83 |year=2005 |pmid=15571876 |doi=10.1016/j.jenvrad.2004.05.015 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0265-931X(04)00200-0}}</ref>
Several sources have attributed the increase in the rate of birth defects in the children of [[Gulf War]] veterans and in Iraqis to depleted uranium inhalation exposure,<ref name=Domingo01/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0165-7992(90)90130-C |author1=Q. Y. Hu |author2=S. P. Zhu |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Induction of chromosomal aberrations in male mouse germ cells by uranyl fluoride containing enriched uranium |journal=[[Mutation Research (journal)|Mutation Research]] |volume=244 |issue=3 |pages=209–214 |date=July 1990 |pmid=2366813 |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |url=http://www.emro.who.int/imemrf/Sci_Med_J_1998_10_1_97.pdf}}</ref> A 2001 study of 15,000 February 1991 U.S. Gulf War combat veterans and 15,000 control veterans found that the Gulf War veterans were 1.8 (fathers) to 2.8 (mothers) times more likely to have children with birth defects.<ref>{{cite journal |author=H. Kang, C. Magee, C. Mahan, K. Lee, F. Murphy, L. Jackson & G. Matanoski |title=Pregnancy outcomes among U.S. Gulf War veterans: a population-based survey of 30,000 veterans |journal=[[Annals of Epidemiology]] |volume=11 |issue=7 |pages=504–511 |date=October 2001 |pmid=11557183 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1047-2797(01)00245-9 |doi=10.1016/S1047-2797(01)00245-9}}</ref> In a study of UK troops, "Overall, the risk of any malformation among pregnancies reported by men was 50% higher in Gulf War Veterans (GWV) compared with Non-GWVs". The conclusion of the study stated ''"We found no evidence for a link between paternal deployment to the Gulf war and increased risk of stillbirth, chromosomal malformations, or congenital syndromes. Associations were found between fathers' service in the Gulf war and increased risk of miscarriage and less well-defined malformations, but these findings need to be interpreted with caution as such outcomes are susceptible to recall bias. The finding of a possible relationship with renal anomalies requires further investigation. There was no evidence of an association between risk of miscarriage and mothers' service in the gulf."''<ref>{{cite journal |author=Pat Doyle, Noreen Maconochie, Graham Davies, Ian Maconochie, Margo Pelerin, Susan Prior & Samantha Lewis |title=Miscarriage, stillbirth and congenital malformation in the offspring of UK veterans of the first Gulf war |journal=[[International Journal of Epidemiology]] |volume=33 |issue=1 |pages=74–86 |date=February 2004 |pmid=15075150 |doi=10.1093/ije/dyh049 |url=http://ije.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/full/33/1/74}}</ref>
===Animals=== It has been reported that uranium has caused [[reproductive]] defects, and other health problems in [[rodents]], [[frog]]s and other animals. Uranium was shown to have cytotoxic, genotoxic and carcinogenic effects in animal studies.<ref>{{cite journal |author=R. H. Lin, L. J. Wu, C. H. Lee & S. Y. Lin-Shiau |title=Cytogenetic toxicity of uranyl nitrate in Chinese hamster ovary cells |journal=[[Mutation Research (journal)|Mutation Research]] |volume=319 |issue=3 |pages=197–203 |date=November 1993 |pmid=7694141 |doi=10.1016/0165-1218(93)90079-S}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=A. C. Miller, C. Bonait-Pellie, R. F. Merlot, J. Michel, M. Stewart & P. D. Lison |title=Leukemic transformation of hematopoietic cells in mice internally exposed to depleted uranium |journal=[[Mol. Cell. Biochem.|Molecular and Cellular Biochemistry]] |volume=279 |issue=1–2 |pages=97–104 |date=November 2005 |pmid=16283518 |doi=10.1007/s11010-005-8226-z}}{{closed access}}</ref> It has been shown in [[rodent]]s and [[frog]]s that water-soluble forms of uranium are [[teratogenic]].<ref name="pmid16124873" /><ref name=Arfsten01/><ref name=Domingo01/>
===Bacterial biochemistry=== It has been shown that bacteria, and [[proteobacteria]] such as [[Geobacter]] and ''[[Burkholderia fungorum]]'' ''(strain Rifle)'', can [[redox|reduce]] and fix uranium in soil and [[groundwater]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Joanna C. Renshaw, Laura J. C. Butchins, Francis R. Livens, Iain May, John M. Charnock & Jonathan R. Lloyd |title=Bioreduction of uranium: environmental implications of a pentavalent intermediate |journal=[[Environ. Sci. Technol.|Environmental Science & Technology]] |volume=39 |issue=15 |pages=5657–5660 |year=2005 |pmid=16124300 |doi=10.1021/es048232b|bibcode = 2005EnST...39.5657R }}{{closed access}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|title=Stimulating the in situ activity of Geobacter species to remove uranium from the groundwater of a uranium-contaminated aquifer.|authors=Anderson RT, Vrionis HA, Ortiz-Bernad I, Resch CT, Long PE, Dayvault R, Karp K, Marutzky S, Metzler DR, Peacock A, White DC, Lowe M, Lovley DR.|year=2003|pmid=14532040|volume=69|issue=10|pages=5884–91|doi=10.1128/AEM.69.10.5884-5891.2003|pmc=201226}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Spatial Distribution of an Uranium-Respiring Betaproteobacterium at the Rifle, CO Field Research Site|last = Koribanics|first = Nicole M.|date = 13 April 2015|journal = PLOS ONE|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0123378|pmid = 25874721|last2 = Tuorto|first2 = Steven J.|display-authors=etal|pmc=4395306|volume=10|pages=e0123378}}</ref> These bacteria change soluble [[U(VI)]] into the highly insoluble complex-forming [[U(IV)]] ion, hence stopping [[Leaching (chemistry)|chemical leaching]].
===Behavior in soil=== It has been suggested that it is possible to form a ''reactive barrier'' by adding something to the soil which will cause the uranium to become fixed. One method of doing this is to use a mineral ([[apatite]])<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www-ssrl.slac.stanford.edu/research/highlights_archive/u_ha_prb.html |author=Christopher C. Fuller, John R. Bargar & James A Davis |title=Remediation of uranium-contaminated waterat Fry Canyon, Utah |date=November 20, 2003 |publisher=[[Stanford University]]}}</ref> while a second method is to add a food substance such as [[acetate]] to the soil. This will enable bacteria to reduce the uranium (VI) to uranium (IV) which is much less soluble. In [[peat]]-like soils the uranium will tend to bind to the [[humic acids]], this tends to fix the uranium in the soil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.magnet.fsu.edu/publications/2000annualreview/pdfs/NHMFL2000AR-Geochemistry.pdf |title=Geochemistry |format= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041212095102/http://www.magnet.fsu.edu/publications/2000annualreview/pdfs/NHMFL2000AR-Geochemistry.pdf |archivedate=December 12, 2004 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
{{Pollution}} {{Environmental science}} {{Uranium mining}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=January 2007}} '''User expectations''' refers to the consistency that users expect from products. [[Interaction design]] is very concerned with this topic. For example, our user expectations for traffic behavior is one of the more consistent ones because it is governed by [[traffic law]]s that are enforced. [[Software]], or even worse small [[consumer electronics]], on the other hand, can have widely varying degrees of consistency.
A good [[rule of thumb]] or ''design principle'' to use in interaction design is to follow the "[[Principle of least astonishment]]". In the case of interactive [[software application]]s, for example, users form expectations based on their experience with similar kinds of software. Effective [[software design]] aims to conform with prevailing norms for aspects of behavior such as the software's [[user interface]] and its [[responsiveness]].
A commonly noted sign of poor [[usability]] and [[human factors]] due to the violation of user expectations is when [[information sign|signs]] are needed for common things like doors. This was made famous by [[Donald A. Norman]] in his seminal book [[The Psychology of Everyday Things]]. There is also a website devoted to such Bad Designs [http://baddesigns.com].
==See also==
*[[User experience design]]
==External links== *[http://www.adaptivepath.org/publications/essays/archives/000272.php User Expectations in a World of Smart Devices, by Mike Kuniavsky] *[http://webword.com/moving/expectations.html Managing User Expectations, by John Rhodes] *[http://www.scottberkun.com/essays/5-how-to-avoid-foolish-consistency/ How to Avoid Foolish Consistency], by [[Scott Berkun]]
[[Category:Design]]

==Ward-Beck Systems Preservation Society (WBSPS)== The [http://wbsps.kuzub.com Ward-Beck Systems Preservation Society] was founded in 2005 by [[Tony Kuzub]]. The goal and objective of the WBSPS is to keep vintage Ward-Beck equipment running and working by supplying a database of documentation, knowledge, and support. There are only a handful of consoles still in existence and use, and the WBSPS is dedicated to keeping these consoles in use and maintained. Many manuals have been scanned in their entirety and posted for all to learn from. The WBSPS was given permission by [[Eugene Johnson]] of [[Ward-Beck]] to publish information regarding vintage WBS equipment.<ref>http://wbsps.Kuzub.com</ref> The WBSPS is not directly or in-directly associated with Ward-Beck Systems Incorporated. [http://wbsps.kuzub.com/Letter%20from%20Eugene%20at%20Ward-Beck%20Systems.jpg A Letter of permission from Ward-Beck Systems]

[[File:Wells Print Shop (2018).jpg|thumb|250x250px|Myers Jewelry (formerly Wells Print Shop), 2018]] The '''Wells Print Shop''' was located at 27 Cuna Street in [[St. Augustine, Florida]]. It operated as part of the [[Historic St. Augustine Preservation Board]]'s 18th century museum village, San Agustín Antiguo, demonstrating the colonial printmaking process.<mapframe latitude="29.8949" longitude="-81.3152" zoom="15" width="250" height="200" align="right"> { "type": "FeatureCollection", "features": [ { "type": "Feature", "properties": {}, "geometry": { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ -81.3126586677936, 29.895805875537548 ] } } ] } </mapframe>
== William Wells == [[William Charles Wells]] was born in 1757 in [[Charleston, South Carolina]], the son of a [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Tory]] printer, publisher, and bookseller. He was formally trained as a doctor, receiving a degree in medicine from the [[University of Edinburgh]] in 1780. When the British left Charleston in 1782, William and his brother John moved to St. Augustine where they established a print shop. In St. Augustine the Wells brothers are most well known for publishing the ''East Florida Gazette'', the first newspaper in Florida. After the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|1783 Treaty of Paris]] returned Florida to the Spanish, William Wells went to England and practiced medicine for the rest of his life. He died in London in 1817.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=October 1986|title=Two Noteworthy Acquisitions for the WHL in 1985-86|url=|journal=Waring Library Society Newsletter|volume=9|pages=3-4|via=}}</ref>
== ''East Florida Gazette'' == The Wells brothers' publication began on February 1, 1783 and lasted a little over one year, with the last issue published on March 22, 1784. London's Public Record Office only contains three issues of the newspaper, those from March 1, May 3, and May 17, 1783. The St. Augustine Historical Society resurrected the name "East Florida Gazette" with its newsletter, which is indexed on the Historical Society Research Library's online catalog.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.saintaugustinehistoricalsociety.org/research-library/|title=St. Augustine Historical Society - Research Library|website=www.saintaugustinehistoricalsociety.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Wells Print Shop.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Wells Print Shop, 1971]] The Historic St. Augustine Preservation Board reconstructed the Wells Print Shop in 1968 on Cuna Street. The original Wells printing press owned by William and John was located on Treasury Lane. The all-wooden shop was constructed using board-and-[[batten]] building method, which the British settlers in St. Augustine preferred for its quick construction and ease of repair. The building is 220 square feet.
Inside the print shop was a replica of the type of printing press used towards the end of the 18th century. The press was operated daily to demonstrate the printing process to visitors, but the Preservation Board also used it to make reproductions of historic St. Augustine maps and replicas of the ''East Florida Gazette,'' which were sold as souvenirs.
Today the site once occupied by the Wells Print Shop operates as a jewelry store.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.myersjewelryandgifts.com/|title=Myers Jewelry and Gifts|website=www.myersjewelryandgifts.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Crafts]] [[Category:Printing]] [[Category:Industries]] [[Category:Florida]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in St. Augustine, Florida]]
